overload.translation[0].definitions[0].d: to put too many things or people on or into something
overload.translation[0].definitions[0].e: Be careful not to overload the washing machine.
The bus was overloaded with tourists and their luggage.
overload.translation[0].definitions[1].d: to put too much electricity through an electrical system or piece of equipment
overload.translation[0].definitions[2].d: to give someone too much work or information to deal with
overload.translation[0].definitions[2].e: All the staff are overloaded with work.
overload.translation[1].definitions[0].d: to give someone more work, information etc than they can deal with
overload.translation[1].definitions[0].e: Don’t overload your buyer with too much information.
overload.translation[1].definitions[1].d: if something is overloaded with a particular problem, it is badly affected by that problem
overload.translation[1].definitions[1].e: The economy was overloaded with so much debt that a real depression was possible.
